message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy would be acetaminophen as it does not cause GI upset or bleeding. Ibuprofen and naproxen may aggravate the peptic ulcer disease, and oxycodone may cause respiratory depression, which is not necessary for mild back pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for pain relief would be acetaminophen, which does not irritate the gastrointestinal tract. Naproxen and ibuprofen are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that can cause gastric irritation, and oxycodone is a stronger pain reliever and is not indicated for mild back pain. An x-ray of the spine shows no abnormalities, ruling out more serious causes of back pain such as fractures or tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acetaminophen is a first-line medication for mild to moderate back pain, especially for patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease who should avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as Naproxen and Ibuprofen. Oxycodone is a powerful opioid and should be reserved for severe pain or when other treatments have failed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a muscular injury rather than a structural one, and therefore, treatment with acetaminophen is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy. Opioids like oxycodone should be avoided if possible due to the risk of addiction and side effects. Naproxen and ibuprofen are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which can cause gastrointestinal side effects and therefore not the best initial treatment option for a patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has no red flags such as fever, chills, or weight loss and the x-ray shows no abnormalities. Therefore, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy is acetaminophen for mild pain. Oxycodone is a stronger opioid analgesic and is generally reserved for more severe pain. Naproxen and ibuprofen are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that can also be used for pain relief, but have a higher risk of gastrointestinal side effects, which may be problematic in a patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acetaminophen is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy as it is effective for mild to moderate pain and has a lower risk of gastrointestinal side effects compared to NSAIDs like naproxen and ibuprofen. Oxycodone is a stronger pain medication that is more appropriate for severe pain and should not be used as initial treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease, NSAIDs like Naproxen and Ibuprofen should be avoided. Acetaminophen is a better option for pain relief in this case. Oxycodone is a stronger pain medication and is not usually the first line of treatment for lower back pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has mild back pain and no significant findings on examination or x-ray, suggesting a likely musculoskeletal cause. Acetaminophen is a first-line therapy for mild to moderate musculoskeletal pain, and is preferable to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease. NSAIDs may also increase the risk of cardiovascular events in some patients. Opioids such as oxycodone are generally reserved for severe pain or when other treatments are ineffective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a musculoskeletal cause, specifically mechanical low back pain. Acetaminophen is a first-line treatment for this type of pain and is safer for patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease compared to NSAIDs (such as naproxen and ibuprofen). Opioids (such as oxycodone) are not recommended as initial therapy for acute low back pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has mild lower back pain without any significant findings on examination and imaging studies. Acetaminophen is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for mild to moderate pain. It is safer for patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease compared to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like naproxen and ibuprofen, and has a lower risk of addiction compared to opioids like oxycodone.
